string-array.name: abbreviation_list_child
string-array.item: Advance Audio Coding \n\nAAC is defined as Audio Coding which is able to provide better sound quality.
Artificial Intelligence \n\nAI refers to the programming installed in a machine which allows the machine to understand and operate in the modern world.
Business-to-Business \n\nB2B represents transactions and interactions between two businesses rather than between a business and individual consumers.
Beginners All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code \n\nBASIC is a programming language designed for beginners to learn programming concepts.
Computer-Aided Design \n\nCAD is the use of computer technology to aid in the design and analysis of products and systems.
Central Processing Unit \n\nCPU is the primary component of a computer that performs instructions from software programs.
Domain Name System \n\nDNS translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses, enabling efficient web browsing.
Digital Versatile Disc \n\nDVD is a digital optical disc storage format that can be used for storing video, audio, and other data.
Electrocardiogram \n\nEKG, also known as ECG, is a test that measures the electrical activity of the heart.
Enterprise Resource Planning \n\nERP integrates business processes and data into a unified system to enhance efficiency.
File Transfer Protocol \n\nFTP is a standard network protocol used to transfer files from one host to another over a TCP-based network.
Hypertext Markup Language \n\nHTML is the standard markup language used to create web pages.
Intensive Care Unit \n\nICU is a specialized department in a hospital that provides care for critically ill patients.
Internet of Things \n\nIoT refers to the network of physical objects connected to the internet, enabling data exchange and automation.
JavaScript Object Notation \n\nJSON is a lightweight data interchange format used to transmit data between a server and a web application.
Joint Photographic Experts Group \n\nJPEG is a commonly used method of lossy compression for digital images.
Key Performance Indicator \n\nKPI is a measurable value that indicates how effectively a company is achieving its key business objectives.
Kernel-based Virtual Machine \n\nKVM is an open-source virtualization solution that enables running multiple virtual machines on a single host.
Local Area Network \n\nLAN is a network that connects computers and devices within a limited geographic area, such as a home or office.
Learning Management System \n\nLMS is a software application used to deliver, track, and manage online learning and training materials.
Musical Instrument Digital Interface \n\nMIDI is a protocol for communicating musical information between computers, synthesizers, and other devices.
Moving Picture Experts Group \n\nMPEG is a set of standards used for coding audio and video information in a digital compressed format.

Optical Character Recognition \n\nOCR is technology that converts different types of documents, such as scanned paper documents, PDF files, or images taken by a digital camera, into editable and searchable data.
Operating System \n\nOS is software that manages computer hardware, software resources, and provides services for computer programs.

Portable Document Format \n\nPDF is a file format developed by Adobe that captures all the elements of a printed document as electronic images that can be viewed, navigated, and printed from various devices.
Portable Network Graphics \n\nPNG is a raster graphics file format that supports lossless data compression, often used for images displayed on the web.
Quality of Service \n\nQoS refers to the performance levels of a network or computer system, ensuring optimal data transfer and service quality.
Random Access Memory \n\nRAM is a type of computer memory that provides high-speed data access to temporarily store data that the CPU is currently using or processing.
Relational Database Management System \n\nRDBMS is a type of database management system that stores and retrieves data organized in tables with rows and columns.
Read-Only Memory \n\nROM is a type of non-volatile memory used in computers and other electronic devices to store permanent or semi-permanent data.
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol \n\nSMTP is a protocol used to send email messages between servers, ensuring reliable email delivery.
Structured Query Language \n\nSQL is a domain-specific language used for managing and querying relational databases.
Secure Sockets Layer \n\nSSL is a security protocol that establishes an encrypted link between a web server and a browser, ensuring secure data transmission.
Transmission Control Protocol \n\nTCP is a core protocol of the internet protocol suite that facilitates reliable communication between network devices.
Uniform Resource Locator \n\nURL is the web address that specifies the location of a resource on the internet.
Universal Serial Bus \n\nUSB is a standard for connecting various devices to a computer using a common interface.
Video Graphics Array \n\nVGA is a video display standard that was the dominant connector type for computer monitors and displays in the 1990s and early 2000s.
Virtual Private Network \n\nVPN is a secure connection that allows users to access a private network, such as a corporate intranet, over a public network like the internet.
Wide Area Network \n\nWAN is a network that spans a larger geographic area, often connecting multiple smaller networks.
eXtensible Markup Language \n\nXML is a markup language used to encode documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable.
XMLHttpRequest \n\nXHR is a JavaScript object that provides the functionality to transfer data between a web browser and a web server asynchronously.
YAML Aint Markup Language \n\nYAML is a human-readable data serialization format used for configuration files and data exchange between languages with different data structures.
Zone Improvement Plan \n\nZIP codes are a system of postal codes used by the United States Postal Service to efficiently route mail.
Zoology \n\nZoology is the scientific study of animals and their behavior, structure, physiology, classification, and distribution.
